user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemGive_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemGive_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     * Note there is a possibility that another thread is concurrently taking this sem,
     * and has just checked the current_value but not yet inside the cond_wait call.
     *
     * To address this possibility - the lock must be taken here.  This is unfortunate
     * as it means there may be a task switch when _giving_ a binary semaphore.  But the
     * alternative of having a BinSemGive not wake up the other thread is a bigger issue.
     *
     * Counting sems do not suffer from this, as there is a native POSIX mechanism for those.
     *
     * Note: This lock should be readily available, with only minimal delay if any.
     * If a long delay occurs here, it means something is fundamentally wrong.
     */

    /* Lock the mutex ( not the table! ) */
    if (OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(&sem->id) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* Binary semaphores are always set as "1" when given */
    sem->current_value = 1;

    /* unblock one thread that is waiting on this sem */
    pthread_cond_signal(&(sem->cv));

    pthread_mutex_unlock(&(sem->id));

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemGive_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_bin_sem_table[OS_MAX_BIN_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t       id;
    pthread_cond_t        cv;
    volatile sig_atomic_t flush_request;
    volatile sig_atomic_t current_value;
} OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(pthread_mutex_t *mut)
{
    struct timespec timeout;

    if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    timeout.tv_sec += OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS;

    if (pthread_mutex_timedlock(mut, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code fragments found in the provided code with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1. Rationale:

- Control flow: The only early exit is the conditional return when OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(...) != OS_SUCCESS. That return is reachable at runtime (mutex acquisition can fail) and is legitimate; the remaining statements (setting current_value, pthread_cond_signal, pthread_mutex_unlock, and return OS_SUCCESS) are reachable when the mutex acquisition succeeds.

- No statements follow an unconditional return within the same block, and there are no constant-true/false conditions, infinite loops, or labels/jumps that would make subsequent code unreachable.

- Macro expansion (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token)) yields &OS_impl_bin_sem_table[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(*token))], which is effectively &OS_impl_bin_sem_table[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(token)]. This is a valid index expression; the array OS_impl_bin_sem_table is defined, and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken is a simple inline accessor, so there is no compile-time unreachable code introduced by the macro.

- The helper function OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex performs runtime operations (clock_gettime, pthread_mutex_timedlock) that can fail — these are runtime conditions and do not constitute unreachable code.

Because all code paths in the snippet are potentially reachable and there are no dead-code constructs, there are no fragments to flag for investigation under Rule 2.1.
